Award.AwardTitle: Multiparametric Sensor Arrays for High Information Content Separations
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Ryan Bailey and his group at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign aim to perform high information content separations using a silicon photonic microring resonator platform. The focus of this work is to improve analysis of polymers and small molecules, for example, with applications in consumer goods quality control and pharmaceutical drug development. The inherent versatility, quantitative nature, and dynamic range of this analytical platform make it applicable to a wide range of chromatographic detection challenges. In conjunction with the scientific goals of the project, the award will also support the training and development of young scientists, particularly those students from traditionally underrepresented minorities. Furthermore, the group will continue participation in outreach activities within the local community, including an innovative Spanish language science outreach program developed in collaboration with the campus chapter of the Society for the Advancement of Chicanos and Native Americans in Science (SACNAS).

Modified sensor arrays for multiparametric separations can be applied to polymer characterization using tunable organic sensor surfaces, to pharmaceutical biologics validation using immune-affinity characterization, and to integrated on-chip separations with electrophoresis for a lab-on-a-chip devices. The current methods for the analysis of polymer and small molecules suffer from slow product validation and often require multiple analytical methods for complete characterization. This project seeks to simplify the validation process by incorporating rapid and chemically informative separations into a single device, representing a new capability for the separations field. Such a device will prove particularly important in the separation and analysis of the next generation of pharmaceuticals, including antibody-based therapeutics. Unlike more conventional small molecule drugs these biological therapeutics demand unique analytical characterization tools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Microring resonator arrays, which are surface-sensitive refractive index detectors, were explored as detection elements for multiple hyphenated separation methods. These sensors showed good sensitivity and exceptional dynamic range for liquid chromatographic-based separations of industrially-relevant polymer. This application is of general interest as many industrial polymers, such as polyethylene, lack chromophoric signatures that many separation detection approaches need. Furthermore, microring resonators exhibited a sufficient dynamic range to allow tracking of polymer elution using gradient elution methods, which are typically not amenable to simple refractive index-based measurements. It was also found that chemical functionalization of microring sensor surfaces could provide an added element of chemical specificity. This was determined using microrings presenting polymer brushes that could exhibit substantial swelling or collapse dynamics when interacting with particular analytes that matched (or opposed) the chemical functionalities of the polymer brushes themselves. Microring resonators were also found to be enabling sensors when coupled with capillary electrophoretic-based separations. Again, the ability to detect classes of analytes not conventionally monitored using optical absorbance or fluorescence were well-suited to this type of analysis. Furthermore, preliminary results suggest that spatially-distributed arrays of sensors, over which the migrating bands of analyte would flow over sequentially, provided additional insights into the performance of the chromatography itself. Altogether, microring resonators were robustly demonstrated to have high potential at versatile detection elements for chromatographic separation methods and ongoing investigations will continue to explore new applications for this label-free detection modality for a range of (bio)chemical and industrial analytes that in the future will benefit high information content approaches to comprehensively provide information about quantity and chemical composition of complex mixtures.
